The vast, icy land of Antarctica, ''the White Continent,'' has attracted explorers since the early days of the 20th century -- from Roald Amundsen and Ernest Shackleton to Robert Falcon Scott and Richard E. Byrd -- each determined to conquer this unconquerable continent.

The dangers were enormous -- ''For God's sake, hold on, it's got us,'' Shackleton yelled to his crew as a gigantic wave washed over the deck of their 23-foot whaler, the James Caird, nearly capsizing it into the frigid water in 1916 -- and some explorers never came home alive.

But when the photographer Heidi Schumann went to Antarctica in January this year, on a cruise ship, the World (www.aboardtheworld.com), deprivation and life-threatening conditions were far from the minds of her and her several hundred fellow passengers -- not with the boat's hot tub, heated swimming pool, putting green and 24-hour room service.
But the lure of Antarctica, with its massive glaciers, strikingly beautiful vistas and, of course, its penquins, remains as powerful as in the days of its first explorers.
